Now we can perform the quantization of the sys-
tem and proceed to compute the Power Spectrum. We
will first briefly present the standard Spectrum derived
through the canonical quantization，and then find the
modified spectrum coming from the algebra
Here we will compute the standard Power Spectrum.
In the standard representation of Quantum Mechanics,
the two operators corresponding to the Fourier modes
will obey the standard commutation relations and will
\hat { \xi } _ { k } \psi ( \xi _ { k } ) = \xi _ { k } \psi ( \pi _ { k } ) , \quad \hat { \pi } _ { k } \psi ( \xi _ { k } ) = i \frac { \partial } { \partial \xi _ { k } } \psi ( \xi _ { k } ) .
A single Fourier mode has Hamiltonian

i \frac { \partial } { \partial \eta } \psi ( \eta , \xi _ { k } ) = \frac { 1 } { 2 } \left( - \frac { \partial ^ { 2 } } { \partial \xi _ { k } ^ { 2 } } + \omega _ { k } ^ { 2 } ( \eta ) \xi _ { k } ^ { 2 } \right) \psi ( \eta , \xi _ { k } ) .
This is the Schrodinger equation of a harmonic oscillator
with time-dependent frequency. The solution to such a
system can be found through the method of invariants
and is a superposition of the following normalized
\begin{array} { r } { \alpha _ { n } \ = \ \alpha _ { n } ( \eta ) \ = \ - ( n + \frac { 1 } { 2 } ) \int f ^ { - 2 } d \eta } \end{array}

ing its perturbations to the curvature perturbations

is the large scale limit. The expectation value of
computed on the vacuum state i.e. the ground state of
the time-dependent oscillator; we therefore need to know
how to express the result of

\hat { a } ^ { \dagger } = \frac { \frac { \hat { \xi } _ { k } } { f } - i ( f \hat { \pi } _ { k } - f ^ { \prime } \hat { \xi } _ { k } ) } { \sqrt 2 } , \quad \hat { a } ^ { \dagger } \psi _ { n } = \sqrt { n + 1 } e ^ { i \varphi } \psi _ { n + 1 } ;

\hat { a } = \frac { \frac { \hat { \xi } _ { k } } { f } + i \big ( f \hat { \pi } _ { k } - f ^ { \prime } \hat { \xi } _ { k } \big ) } { \sqrt 2 } , \quad \hat { a } \psi _ { n } = \sqrt { n } e ^ { - i \varphi } \psi _ { n - 1 } ;
\hat { \xi } _ { k } \psi _ { n } = f \left( \sqrt { \frac { n + 1 } { 2 } } e ^ { i \varphi } \psi _ { n + 1 } + \sqrt { \frac { n } { 2 } } e ^ { - i \varphi } \psi _ { n - 1 } \right) ,

{ \hat { \pi } } _ { k } \psi _ { n } = i { \frac { R } { f } } { \sqrt { \frac { n + 1 } { 2 } } } e ^ { i \varphi } \psi _ { n + 1 } - i { \frac { R ^ { * } } { f } } { \sqrt { \frac { n } { 2 } } } e ^ { - i \varphi } \psi _ { n - 1 } ,
